_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES.  The accidental release prevention and response policies for the Hiland Bakken Gas Plant are maintained in the facility's Emergency Response Plan and RMP Manual.  Hiland is committed to the safety and health of it's employees, contractors and visitors.  This commitment is demonstrated in the design, operation and maintenance programs developed and implemented specifically for this facility.  Operation and maintenance personnel are trained in the appropriate emergency response procedures to follow in the event of an accidental release.  However, accident prevention is the ultimate goal and as such a site-specific mechanical integrity program is being implemented and maintained.



FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES.  The Hiland Bakken Gas Plant is located approximately 10 miles North of Sidney, Montana, West of Highway 16.  It is a plant that is designed to extract natural gas liquids (ie: ethane, propane, butane and heavier hydrocarbons) from raw natural gas and at the same time produce a pipeline quality gas (primarily methane).  The only process in the plant is storage of flammable substances containing regulatory substances in excess of the 10,000 lb threshold.  Flammable substance storage included butane, propane, natural gasoline, and natural gas condensate. There are no above threshold quantity toxic substances at the Hiland Bakken Gas Plant.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM.  The Hiland Bakken Gas Plant has developed and implemented a site-specific accidental release prevention program that consists of a detailed facility mechanical integrity program and employee training program.  The mechanical integrity program was developed under the guidelines of manufacturer written recommendations,  recognized/generally accepted good engineering practices, industry/regulatory standards and past operation history.  Employee training was designed to ensure/document employee understanding of f

acility operation and maintenance requirements.



WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO.  In accordance with EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR Part 68), the plant's inventory of chemicals was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable or toxic substances were present in quantities above the threshold amount.  It was found that the stored quantities of flammable substances exceeded the 10,000 lb threshold.  These flammable substance are stored in common areas and comprise a single covered process.  No toxic substances exist at the plant in quantities that exceed the threshold.



The worst-case scenario for this facility would be a vapor cloud explosion.  Using EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequences Analysis and the single largest vessel resulting in the greatest distance to an endpoint, the estimated distance of the 1 psi endpoint to the nearest public receptor would be 0.6 miles.  Based on 2000 Census data and Landview, public receptors occur within this distance, resulted in a shift of the facility from Program 1 to a Program 3 level.  



ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO.  A Program 3 facility is required to also perform an offsite consequence analysis for an alternate release scenario.  Using the same procedures described above and the next flammable substance resulting in the greatest distance to an endpoint, the endpoint was determined to be 0.5 miles. It was also determined that public receptors occur within this distance. 



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.  The Hiland Bakken Gas Plant has never had an accidental release that has resulted in offsite consequences.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.  The Hiland Bakken Gas Plant has develped and maintains a site-specific Emergency Response Plan (ERP)  that includes actions to take in the event of an uncontrolled release of a hazardous substance.  The ERP includes the names and phone numbers of company personnel and names and phone numbers of support services (contractors, police departments, fire d

epartments, medical services/hospitals, regulatory agencies, LEPC, etc.) tha may be called upon for assistance.  Liaison with those agencies is maintained to ensure timely and proper responses.  Employee understanding of their responsibilities during and emergency situation is high priority.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY.  Hiland believes safety is an issue that can always be improved upon.  Hiland continues to look for, develop and implement programs that will improve an employee's ability to identify and correct potential workplace hazards.  Hiland also endeavors to ensure policies, programs and procedures are developed and implemented to meet applicable laws, rules and regulations.  Employee understanding of these policies, programs and procedures is high priority.
